item.title: FragPunk console launch delayed as NetEase's shooter hits PC this week
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/fragpunk-console-launch-delayed-as-neteases-shooter-hits-pc-this-week

Compensation will be offered.

After the success of Marvel Rivals, NetEase is publishing another shooter due for release this week: FragPunk. At least, it's releasing on PC, as its console launch has been delayed without a new release date.

The online shooter was first revealed at last year's Xbox Games Showcase in June, showing off its unique card mechanic that alters gameplay and the environments with wacky effects.

FragPunk releases on PC tomorrow, 6th March, but a message from the official social media account states the Xbox and PlayStation releases need more time due to "unexpected technical challenges".

"Since the announcement of the game, your excitement has been truly inspiring, and we know how much you've been looking forward to launching into battle on both Xbox and PlayStation," the announcement reads.

"However, we want to be fully transparent with you: during the console compliance testing process, we encountered unexpected technical challenges in optimisation and adaptation.

"Rather than rushing the console release and providing a potentially poor user experience, we have made the difficult decision to delay the launch of the console versions to ensure that players receive a comparable experience to those on PC."

It's unknown when the console versions will now be released.

However, the developer will compensate players on Xbox and PlayStation by providing all rewards up front, including in-game currencies, cosmetics, experience, and more once the game is out.

Any console pre-orders will be cancelled, but those players will receive in-game currency worth $10 when these versions eventually launch.

"This delay was not an easy decision, but we are committed to delivering the best possible experience for our players, and this additional time will allow us to fully optimise and polish the console versions for launch," the statement continues.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

The PC release of FragPunk will include 150+ Shard Cards, 13 playable heroes (called Lancers), and seven maps to battle on.

FragPunk promises an alternative to Valorant - like Riot's shooter it's a five-versus-five free-to-play shooter with teams taking turns to attack and defend.

I went hands-on with FragPunk at last year's Gamescom and was impressed by both the speed of gameplay and its intriguing card system that should help it stand out from other games of the genre.

item.title: Baldur's Gate 3 fan-favourite pops up again in official D&D lore
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/baldurs-gate-3-fan-favourite-pops-up-again-in-official-dd-lore

"Darling, you are simply delicious..."

Eagle-eyed Dungeons and Dragons fans have spotted a fresh reference to everyone's favourite Baldur's Gate 3 vampire, hidden away in the game's new Monster Manual.

Astarion is featured in the 2025 edition of the Monster Manual - or at least, a quote from him is - as spotted by Baldur's Gate 3 fans on reddit (thanks, GamesRadar).

"Darling, you are simply delicious," Astarion says, atop the Monster Manual page detailing Vampire Spawn (medium or small Undead, Neutral Evil). And this isn't the first time Astarion has popped up in official D&D lore either.

Astarion previously popped up in the official D&D Player's Handbook (2024 edition) as seen in an eye-catching piece of artwork for the daylight spell.

Here, Astarion can be spotted tucked away in the bottom right corner, unafflicted by the spell's effects which have begun to burn up all his vampire spawn brethren. (Astarion canonically is immune to sunlight, thanks to the handy plot device of having his illithid tadpole in his brain).

Last year's handbook did not specifically confirm it was Astarion in the artwork, but ENWorld later got acknowledgement from the illustration's artist that it was an official appearance by the character, the rights to which are owned by D&D maker Wizards of the Coast.

Baldur's Gate 3 developer Larian has now wrapped up work on the game with one final patch that added in Xbox Series S splitscreen support. The studio has now begun work on its next game, but it won't be Baldur's Gate 4 or anything at all to do with D&D. Still, it's highly likely we will see a new entry in the series launch at some point - even if it is from another developer.

item.title: Nintendo wins another lawsuit, this time against counterfeit amiibo sellers on Amazon
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/nintendo-wins-another-lawsuit-this-time-against-counterfeit-amiibo-sellers-on-amazon

Awarded over $7m in damages.

Nintendo has won another lawsuit this week, this time against a pair of counterfeit sellers selling fake amiibo cards on Amazon.

In October 2023, Nintendo and Amazon filed a joint lawsuit against the counterfeiters for allegedly selling fake Nintendo goods, but the sellers failed to respond.

Now a Seattle district judge has issued a default judgement in the companies' favour, awarding over $7m in trademark infringement damages (thanks Polygon).

Specifically, Nintendo sought $705,963 against one seller through several seller accounts, $6.2m against another seller with several accounts, and $47,652 against both for a shared account.

"The Court finds this damages request to be reasonable, in light of the nature of the deceptive scheme, the scope of the sales, the involvement of each Defendant, as well as the need for compensation, deterrence, and punishment," court documents read. "The Court therefore awards Nintendo damages in the amounts and allocations sought."

Amazon shut down the sellers' accounts ahead of filing the original complaint.

"Nintendo utilises both internal and external resources to combat counterfeit and infringing products," wrote lawyers in that original complaint. "Nintendo works with a third-party brand protection service vendor on the detection and removal of product listings violating Nintendo's IP rights that are identified and sold in Amazon's stores. Nintendo works regularly and collaboratively with Amazon to identify counterfeit Nintendo products and to strengthen automated detection and removal of the products from Amazon's stores."

The news follows an announcement from Nintendo yesterday it was successful in a lawsuit against French file-sharing company Dstorage, which operates the website 1fichier.com. The decision was "significant" in the company's ongoing fight against pirated games, as well as for "the entire games industry".

Other lawsuit wins include against Switch emulator Yuzu, which shut down and paid Nintendo $2.4m, as well as against a streamer who broadcast pirated games last year.

Perhaps the most high-profile legal action from Nintendo, though, is its ongoing patent infringement lawsuit against Palworld developer Pocketpair. The Pokémon-with-guns game has surpassed 32 million players a year after its release, but the legal case currently remains unresolved.
